title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.15.35 | 21-12-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: Om Agyana Timiraandasya Gyananjanishalakaya Chakshurunmeelitam Yena Tasmai Shri Gurave Namaha
segments.summary: The lecture begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers, invoking blessings and paying respects to the spiritual lineage.

segments.key_quote: The Supreme Lord relinquished the body which he manifested to diminish the burden of the earth.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the verse from Srimad Bhagavatam (1.15.35) and explains its meaning, focusing on the Lord's appearance and disappearance.

segments.key_quote: So impersonal philosophy is that God is impersonal, God has no transcendental personality no personality and the widest philosophy is God is void, shunya, formless, no form at all.
segments.summary: The speaker discusses the impersonal and voidist philosophies, contrasting them with the Vaishnava understanding of God's personal form and Srila Prabhupada's role in countering these philosophies in the West.

segments.key_quote: the Supreme Lord Personality of Godhead is not impersonal, he is not formless, but his body is non different from him.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on the Vaishnava understanding of the Supreme Lord's eternal, blissful form, drawing from authentic scriptures and referencing Brahma Samhita.

segments.key_quote: That Krishna's form or body is never material, though it may appear like that, it may appear like that, but it is not material, it is completely spiritual.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes that Krishna's form is entirely spiritual, not material, and quotes the Brihad-Vaishnava Tantra to support this point, highlighting the differences between material and spiritual bodies.

segments.key_quote: he displays different kinds of forms suitable for the pastime suitable for the past so the pastime requires Krishna to display his form as a small child of mother Yashoda he displays that form
segments.summary: The speaker addresses the apparent changes in Krishna's form during His pastimes, explaining that these are displays for the sake of the pastimes and do not affect His eternal, spiritual nature.

segments.key_quote: one should never consider the supreme lord's form to be made of material energy or material matter it is not a material form our form this form is made of matter
segments.summary: The speaker continues quoting the Brihad-Vaishnava Tantra, warning against associating with those who consider the Lord's body material and emphasizing the need for purification from such contamination.

segments.key_quote: so what is it that is described as born it is the body body is come to nat√ºrlich body is born body is changing body is aging body is becoming infected with disease not the soul not the spirit not the real you so please understand this
segments.summary: The speaker distinguishes between the material body, which is subject to birth, death, and disease, and the eternal spiritual self, emphasizing the importance of understanding this difference.

segments.key_quote: the Lord's dying or quitting his body is like the jugglery of a magician this is proper explanation the magician shows by his tricks that he is cut into pieces burnt to ashes or made unconscious by hypnotic influences but all are false shows
segments.summary: The speaker uses the analogy of a magician to explain how the Lord's apparent death or changes are like illusions, not affecting His true, eternal nature.

segments.key_quote: Similarly, the Lord has his eternal forms of unlimited variety, of which the fish incarnation was exhibited within this universe, which was exhibited in this universe is also one of them.
segments.summary: Continuing the magician analogy, the speaker explains that the Lord's various incarnations, like the fish incarnation, are exhibitions of His eternal forms, not transformations.

segments.key_quote: So, his pastimes are continuously going on, it appears like here some changes are happening, but actually his Leela is going on, he is not changing.
segments.summary: The speaker describes how Krishna's pastimes are continuously unfolding in different universes simultaneously, creating the appearance of change while His eternal Leela remains constant.

segments.key_quote: Dhatte means eternally accepted, not temporarily accepting something.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the word 'dhatte,' meaning eternally accepted, to highlight that the Lord's incarnations are not temporary but eternal forms.

segments.key_quote: They think that I am formless. And they also have a theory that I accept a form to serve a purpose. Because of which I am now manifested as a human being.
segments.summary: The speaker quotes verses from the Bhagavad Gita (7.24-25) to refute the impersonalists' view that the Lord is formless and only accepts forms temporarily, explaining that the Lord's true nature is concealed by His yoga maya from non-devotees.
